hivewrongseason: Hive will not swarm until Spring.
blockhelp-claypothive-empty-notop: Pick ceramic brood pot up in empty bag slot
blockhelp-claypothive-empty-withtop: Right click removes honey pot, or use populated skep.
blockhelp-claypothive-populated-withtop: Right click removes honey pot, wax ring indicates harvestable.
blockhelp-ceramichive-empty-notop: Use populated skep to start colony
blockhelp-ceramichive-populated-withtop: Right click removes honey pot, wax ring indicates harvestable.
blockhelp-honeypot-raw: Place in a pitkiln to fire.
blockhelp-honeypot-harvestable: Use a knife to harvest your comb
blockhelp-langstrothsuper-broodtop: Place matching brood box top to create brood box.
blockhelp-langstrothsuper-createstack: Place a langstroth piece to create stack
blockhelp-langstrothstack: Add or remove blocks from stack
fromgoldencombsguide-text:
"How doth the little busy bee
Improve each shining hour
and gather honey all the day
From every opening flower!"
 - Isaac Watts


Advanced Apiculture 101 - From Golden Combs
The bee is domesticated but not tamed
William Longgood

To start on your new apiary adventure, you first must acquire clay, either fire clay or blue clay will do. This clay is used to make a raw brood pot, and a raw honey pot. After firing your ceramic hive parts, pick it up in a backpack slot and place it in a place with plenty of flowers.

Populating Your Hive
Your next step is to find a wild hive with a standard skep. Once you have a populated skep, simply place it in the hive base by right-clicking the ceramic brood pot with it. Set your empty and fired honey pot on top of your new hive by , and wait.

Harvesting Your Hive
When you see a wax ring around the top of the hive, it's time to collect your harvest! Just pick up the honey pot again, set it on the ground, and clean it out with a knife. Now take the empty honey pot and put it back on the hive base.

Growing Your Apiary
Be warned, ceramic hives may be reusable, but they won't swarm to new hives. You'll have to fill new skeps to make new ceramic hives.


Advanced Apiculture 102 - Langstroth Hives
The hum of bees is the voice of the garden
Elizabeth Lawrence

Langstroth Hive takes a significant amount of work to get into operation, but once you do, you'll never want for honey or wax again. Getting your new hive going requires linen, a copious amount of wax, and plenty of boards.

You'll start by building a base for your hive. Next you'll need a super and a brood box.. You'll also want to have a frame rack to line and maintain your bee frames. They then need to be placed in the frame rack and lined by them with a frame liner before being placed in the super.

Start Keepin' Them Bees!
Now that you have all the parts you'll need, it's time to get you some bees! As with the ceramic hive, you'll need to get yourself a skep with a bee colony in it. Place them in the brood box in the same manner and you have an active brood box!

Just one step left. You need to build a hive! Start by placing the base, and placing up to 4 supers on it with up to 10 lined frames inside. Then top it off with a Brood Box holding an active hive!

You're now in business! The hive will report how many harvestable frames it has in it when you look at it. The hive fills from the top down, and is capable of holding up to 40 frames by default! Take note, if you have a large hive inside, it will fill up to two frames in the same time that a skep will fill once. Each frame returns approximately the same as a skep does.


Harvesting And Maintaining Your Frames

Once you have harvestable frames, you'll need to place them in the frame rack, and use a knife to get the comb off. Doing this will slightly damage the frame, and your knife. When your frame breaks, you'll get an empty frame back, which you can refill with a Frame Liner. You can also repair it before it breaks by using waxed twine on it while it's in a frame rack.
fromgoldencombs:block-handbooktext-ceram:
This is the foundation of a hive made from clay pots, and can only be carried in an empty bag slot. Interact with it using a populated skep to fill it with a bee colony, and then place a honey pot on top of it.

Egyptians first kept bees in clay pots made from the Nile River mud, and would even ferry the hives downriver to fertilize a wide variety of crops.
fromgoldencombs:block-handbooktext-hivet: This pot is placed atop the ceramic brood pot. If the hive is active and there are enough flowers, it will eventually form a wax ring, indicating that it's time to harvest! Take it off, place it on the ground, and scrape it with a knife to remove the honeycomb. Place it back on the hive, and it will be ready for your bees to fill again!
fromgoldencombs:block-handbooktext-frame: The frame rack is a covenient tool for holding frames that need to be scraped clean, repaired, or filled with a frame liner. Place the frame in the rack, use waxed twine or waxed linen to repair it. You can use a knife to remove honeycomb so you can replace it in the hive.
fromgoldencombs:block-handbooktitle-lang: Langstroth Hive Base - Held in Bag Slots Only!
fromgoldencombs:block-handbooktext-langs: This is one of the three block components required to make a Langstroth hive. As the name implies it needs to be at the bottom of the stack. You can add a Langstroth Super by it. Top it off with a brood box.
fromgoldencombs:block-handbooktitle-lang: Langstroth Brood Box - Held in Bag Slots Only!
fromgoldencombs:block-handbooktext-langs: This is the part of your Langstroth Hive that holds your colony of bees. It is created by with a Langstroth Super with no bee frames in it with a brood box top of the same colors. Once created, you place a colony in it by it with a populated skep, this can only be done with the brood box on the ground. Then place it on top of a Langstroth Hive composed of a base and at least one super.
fromgoldencombs:block-handbooktitle-lang: Lagnstroth Superstructure - Held in Bag Slots Only!
fromgoldencombs:block-handbooktext-langs:
This structure is where you'll place your bee frames. for your bees to fill. It can made in any combination of two colors of langstroth panels to create a distinct appearance for your hive.
You can open and close it while on the ground by it while highlighting a hotbar slot, or pick it up (if closed) while highlighting an empty bag slot (Ctrl+1-4). When it's open you can fill it with up to 10 lined frames.
When placed in a complete hive your bees will, over time, turn these bee frames into harvestable frames. A complete hive consists of a base, at least one super (with at least one lined frame), and topped by a brood box..
item-handbooktext-langstrothbroodtop: Use this to create a brood box by an empty super with the same wood pattern. These can be made from the combination of any two wood types of bee frames. It can be made out of anyh combination of two colors of Langstroth parts.
item-handbooktext-langstrothside: A component used in making super, base, frame rack, and brood box top in Langstroth Hives.
item-handbooktext-emptybeeframe: The foundation that your bees will build their comb on. It's not ready yet though! You need to place it in a frame rack and then right-click it with a frame liner to create a lined frame.
item-handbooktext-linedbeeframe: This is a frame ready to be placed into a super for your bees to build comb on. When it's ready to be harvested you just take it out, place it in a frame rack and right-click it with a knife to collect honeycomb. This will also damage the frame. You can repair it using waxed twine in a frame rack. If you allow it to break completely, it will become an empty frame. You can then reline it with a frame liner.
item-handbooktext-harvestablebeeframe: This frame is ready to harvest! Just place it in a frame rack and scrape off the honey with a knife to get honeycomb. You'll damage the frame a little doing it, but they can be repaired with waxed twine in a frame rack. If the frame breaks, you can replace the frame liner.
item-handbooktext-frameliner: Frame liners are created using waxed linen, and a knife. They are then used to line empty frames in a frame rack.
item-handbooktext-waxedlfaxtwine: This twine is used for repairing lined frame in a frame rack.
fromgoldencombs:nonemptysuper: The super must be empty to convert to a brood box.
